data.title: Scroll lagging with version 1.19.4
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Scrolling is very laggy since updated to 1.19.4

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open up Atom
2. Scroll.

**Expected behavior:** Scrolls naturally.

**Actual behavior:** Scrolls very slow and lags.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time.

### Versions

1.19.4

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Update autocompletions
data.body: For CSS, HTML, and the Atom API (to Atom 1.19's API docs).

data.title: Update languages
data.body:
All patch releases this time, mostly just small bugfixes and additions here and there.

* language-css
  * More grid keywords
* language-gfm
  * New bullet point snippet
* language-java
  * Tokenize string parameters
* language-javascript
  * Add `.mjs`
* language-sass
  * Tokenize the `$=` ends-with selector
* language-shellscript
  * Tokenize heredoc with spaces

data.title: Welcome Guides are shown on every startup
data.body:
I recently updated two packages (not sure which). After Atom reloaded, it reset a lot of my personal settings, like the font I was using and the syntax theme. It also showed the welcome guides (Atom's welcome guide, Nuclide's welcome guide and the Telemetry opt-in) again.

I could reset my other settings and get rid of the Telemetry opt-in dialog, but these ** welcome guides show up every time (!) I reload Atom, even if I close them before reloading Atom. Is there any chance to get rid of these dialogs? It's quite annoying, especially because one of these guides is shown in a separate tab.

The WelcomeÂ Page and the Welcome Guide also show up if I run Atom in --safe mode. Only Nuclide's welcome guide is missing then.

data.title: Middle-clicking causing scroll to show up instead of closing tabs if atom has multiple tabs open
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Middle-clicking causing scroll to show up instead of closing tabs if atom has multiple tabs open

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a empty atom window
2. open a new tab like 20 times `cmd+n` on mac
3. middle click on a tab

**NOTE**: on mouse up of middle click on mouse, it causes a scroller to pop up to get rid of the scroller you have to click again.
Gif:

![scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5624870/29781715-fdf4b80c-8bce-11e7-9232-c8332c78ae6c.gif)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Closes the tab

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Scroller pops up that lets you scroll.


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions


```
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

```

This issue is verified that it is occurring on Mac and Windows. 

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information
This use to work in 1.19.2 and broke in 1.19.3.  Related to change in https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/515


Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

/cc Both @Ben3eeE and @MattCz reported this issue.
/cc @nathansobo @as-cii this is a regression from https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/515

data.title: Editor window scrolling sensitivity has changed since updating to 1.19.3
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Since updating to 1.19.3, scrolling in the main text window is slower than it used to be. I'm using a late 2016 MacBook Pro with track pad. The reduction in speed is so noticeable that it's actually possible to scroll your fingers up or down the track pad slowly and Atom will fail to scroll at all.

I've reproduced this both with all my extensions enabled and in Safe Mode.

Unfortunately I don't know which version of Atom I was on prior to updating to 1.19.3.

Other apps continue to scroll at the normal pace.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Scroll two fingers slowly up or down the track pad.
2. Atom scrolls the editor window more slowly than it should. When done slowly enough, Atom fails to scroll at all.

**Expected behavior:**

Atom's scroll speed matches that of other applications.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom scrolls more slowly than other applications.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

OS: macOS 10.12.3
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.3

data.title: macOS: ShipIt cached .app becomes the default one when using open utility
data.body:
Just fyi, ShipIt's copy of Atom.app persists past the update. Apparently it's supposed to keep 2 copies there (according to [this](https://discuss.atom.io/t/com-github-atom-shipit-is-using-10-gb-of-space/18461)), but that's not a good idea given macOS has Spotlight which locates apps everywhere. I have no idea how the cached ShipIt app becomes the default atom app when issuing `open file.html -a atom` in a terminal however.

Either way, you might wish to reconsider caching apps at all, or at least zip them or something. Another option would be to figure out how Spotlight and/or the `open` utility handles the default called app and probably prohibit indexing of that folder, no idea.

Thanks.

Edit: the only reason I figured this out is because I force quit the second Atom app (it won't open location when right clicking the app because of its obscure location I suppose), which probably left it in an unstable state and caused this error:
```
$ open ack.html -a atom

LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application 
/Users/mp/Library/Caches/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.xe2AA3L/Atom.app with error -10810
for the file /Users/mp/Downloads/rawhtml/ack.html.
```

data.title: When searching for a package to install, exact name is excluded from the list
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description When searching for a package to install, using the package's exact name excludes that package from the list. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Go to the `Install` tab in `Settings`. 2. Enter in, verbatim, `react`. **Expected behavior:** The `react` package is in the list of packages I could install. It should probable be the first one. **Actual behavior:** The `react` package isn't in the list at all. However, if I only enter in `reac` (less the `t`), the `react` package shows up. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] always ### Versions atom: 1.19.3 mac os sierra 10.12.6

data.title: Atom seems to use some unneeded resources like CPU or additional GPU making laptop noisy
data.body:
Same issue found on both, Windows 10 and Ubuntu 17.04. Asus laptop with i7 core Intel.
When any version of Atom is used it results in produced noise by ASUS laptop's fan which doesn't exits when Bracket or Sublime is in use. In Atom every file opening, every editing file results in additional fan noise moments and this I have only with e.g Blender 3d when some constant countings are made during editing (constant use of CPU and GPU). I had similar issue with noisy fan or unneeded resources in use when wrong touchpad driver was installed - every scroll using touchpad resulted in additional fan noise. Installing proper driver fixed the issue and I think that there's something with Atom's internal engine to improve.

data.title: TypeError, Atom crashed and now will not work despite reinstall
data.body:
G'day everyone,

Was doing an assignment in Atom and all of a sudden it crashed, everything went blank and it opened up what appeared to be Chrome Dev Tools or something similar, with the console log and this big long error (copied below).

I tried exiting out of dev tools and it did nothing, Atom just remained with a completely blank white screen and the title bar up the top, there was no menu folders or anything. I did have third party (downloaded through Atom) themes and have never performed any of my own editing on any of the config files (because I do not know how to/don't have the requisite experience etc).

After removing all files in AppData\Local and AppData\Roaming, uninstalling and reinstalling three times, following the given solutions bother here (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14085) and here (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5389) and here (https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11868) but unfortunately none of these have worked.

Could any of you wonderful individuals shed some light on this?

Kind regards,
Paul

data.title: Analytics from Packages
data.body:
I do understand the need of analytics but I hate Google having all sort of data from all sorts of sources (they can use any data collected for their use too)

I have the metrics package activated because I want to help atom, but it would be nice to have a list of packages that have analytics in them of a toggle to disable analytics from packages.

I discovered a couple of packages that use it and didn't say much about that.

I feel betrayed :P

data.title: The editor has crashed
data.body:
I am running macOS Sierra 10.12.6 and atom will inevitably crash on me after a few minutes. I don't even have to edit code, it just crashes no matter what I am doing. I believe I have to open a file to edit before it will crash. I have uninstalled and reinstalled numerous times. I really want to use atom, but it's not possible without throwing chairs across the room.

Here is the error I get with a blank white screen where the code, sidebar, etc. used to be:

![screen shot 2017-08-26 at 5 16 35 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14244783/29746078-e642601c-8a82-11e7-89c8-efa8bfe4b058.png)

data.body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29014463/29742660-dd59d1ba-8aa0-11e7-90dc-54975c8cc5dc.png)

This notification from Atom seems old fashioned. How we can improve the design of the notification or it will be improved in future updates?

data.title: Major issue: Atom is creating infinite files and cannot be deleted
data.body:
I created another question about 3 days ago, which was closed because I received a bot reply saying I should reproduce the problem on safe mode, even if I explicitly stated that I could not even get safe mode to launch.
Anyway, my problem started by Atom not opening, the uninstalling option didn't work (it would interrupt the process itself), so I manually deleted the folders and installed atom again.

It worked for a few days, until today, when the problem came back, and atom wouldn't open on any instance, even safe mode.

Now, when trying to delete it, I found out that the program was creating an infinite amount of files, so I can't even delete it manually. It's been trying to delete it for 15 minutes now and it's currently at 90000 files and it just keeps growing. How can I stop this? It's even affecting my PC's performance.

data.title: Can't launch atom on Mac after update 1.19.3 (LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After the latest update to atom (1.19.3), Atom will not launch. It returns an error: 

```
LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.
```

The error appeared when I restarted my Mac and relaunched Atom.

Atom will not launch in safe mode, either.

I tried downloading the 1.19.2 and 1.19.3 .zip files to re-install but neither of them is un-zipping successfully. They have been trying for over an hour and appear frozen at about 40%.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In terminal, enter `atom` or `atom --safe`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Atom would launch

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Error: LSOpenURLsWithRole() failed for the application /Applications/Atom.app with error -10810.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions
Atom 1.19.3
Mac OS X 10.12.6

data.title: 'restorePreviousWindowsOnStart: "no"' doesn't work when opened via context menu option
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->


### Description

This only involves "Open with Atom" context menu option on Windows. Both ON folder and INSIDE folder. Otherwise this option works as it should.

This is a major issue for me because "Window state load time" takes almost a second (919ms) for me to execute. And also because I always need to close all tabs and tree items in sidebar to start working which is tiring when you switch between projects multiple times a day. 



### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set `restorePreviousWindowsOnStart: "no"` 
2. Open project and open some files/windows
3. Close Atom
4. Open the same project using "Open with Atom" context menu option

**Expected behavior:**
Atom opens project with all the folders in sidebar collapsed and without any files/tabs opened

**Actual behavior:**
Atom opens the project with the exact last state when it was closed

**Reproduces how often:**
100%


### Versions
```
Windows 10 Pro 1703 (OS Build: 15063.540)
```
```
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```
```
apm  1.18.4
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 3.6.1
git 2.12.2.windows.2
visual studio
```



### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages




<!--
### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.
-->

data.title: keyframe animation re-triggered on pane-item activated again(after change tab and back).
data.body:
CC @nathansobo, @as-cii

Related #15185(fixed), #15449.

![keyframe-anime-retriggered](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/29739536-1d427a96-8a7b-11e7-889d-c6c27a557abc.gif)

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Switching active pane item(tab) and back changes `editor.element.style.display` from `"none"` to `""`, which cause keyfrmane animation re-triggered.

### Steps to Reproduce

Can reproduce in safe-mode.

1. Prepare style to use keyframe animation on your `style.less`

```less
@keyframes t9md-test-animation {
  from { background-color: red; }
  to { background-color: transparent; }
}

atom-text-editor .t9md-test-flash .region {
  animation-name: t9md-test-animation;
  animation-fill-mode: forwards;
  animation-duration: 10.0s;
  animation-iteration-count: 1;
}
```

2. Open more than two editor(editor1 and editor2) and select lines in editor1.
3. Open chrome dev-console and paste following code.

This code flash selected range which flash disappear after 10sec.

```javascript
(function flashreproduceIssue() {
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  const marker = editor.markBufferRange(editor.getSelectedBufferRange())
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: "highlight", class: "t9md-test-flash"})
  setTimeout(function () {
    marker.destroy()
    console.log("destroyed");
  }, 10000);
})()
```

4. Within 10 sec, re-activate editor1 by switch to different item(=editor2) and back. See once fadeout-ed flash is restarted on editor1 become active again.


Keyfrmane animation is re-triggered when `editor.element.style.display` prop changed from `"none"` to `""`.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Don't re-trigger keyframe animation.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

keyframe restarted

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.20.0-beta4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

This article was helpful to understand this issue.
https://codepen.io/derekjp/post/keyframe-animations-display-vs-visibility

data.title: Recreated highlight node re-trigger keyframe animation on contained line-tile changed
data.body:
CC @nathansobo, @as-cii

Similar to #15185 except
- This issue happens even in v1.18.0(before editor rewrite).
- Different condition than #15185.

![decoration-node-recreated](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/29739218-583417d4-8a73-11e7-9d7e-f0053a89a9e1.gif)


I understand fixing this is not easy but hope fixed.
Thanks for great work as always.

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=âœ“&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description


When highlight node is **moved** to different lines-tile, highlight node on existing lines-tile re-created and re-trigger keyframe animation.

### Steps to Reproduce

Can reproduce in safe-mode.

1. Prepare style to use keyframe animation on your `style.less`

```less
@keyframes t9md-test-animation {
  from { background-color: red; }
  to { background-color: transparent; }
}

atom-text-editor .t9md-test-flash .region {
  animation-name: t9md-test-animation;
  animation-fill-mode: forwards;
  animation-duration: 10.0s;
  animation-iteration-count: 1;
}
```

2. Open editor and prepare following text and select `line 2` to `line5`

```

line 2
line 3
line 4
line 5
```

3. Open chrome dev-console and paste following code.

This code copy selected text to clipboard and flash selected range which flash disappear after 10sec.

```javascript
(function flashreproduceIssue() {
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  editor.copySelectedText()
  const marker = editor.markBufferRange(editor.getSelectedBufferRange())
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: "highlight", class: "t9md-test-flash"})
  setTimeout(function () {
    marker.destroy()
    console.log("destroyed");
  }, 10000);
})()
```

4. Within 10 sec, move to point `[0, 0]` and paste from clipboard and see original flash( keyframe animation ) is re-triggered.

What is happening here is
- Pasting 4 lines of text create new lines-tile and inserted **before** old line-tile
- At this timing, highlight node in old lines-tile is re-rendered.
- Which result in re-trigger of keyframe animation.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Don't re-trigger keyframe animation.
Want highlight decoration node being stable once created.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

highlight decoration node is re-created when rendered line-tiles are changed.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.20.0-beta4
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

Actual issue happened in https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/843.

data.title: UX Bug with Git Panel
data.body: When you have multiple project folders open, the git panel should know which project you're working in. E.g. For the current highlighted item within the project view, which project is it? If it's changed, switch the context of the git panel.

data.title: TextEditor rewrite data-grammar attribute updating regression
data.body:
### Description
It seems like there's a regression with the TextEditor rewrite. The specs for my package [css-declaration-sorter-atom](https://github.com/Siilwyn/css-declaration-sorter-atom) suddenly started failing. @Arcanemagus found out that if you place a breakpoint at [main-spec.js#L39](https://github.com/Siilwyn/css-declaration-sorter-atom/blob/68825124d8c312376a4d809995935c1c1390aefb/spec/main-spec.js#L39) then `editor.getGrammar()` shows what you expect, but the `data-grammar` property of [main-spec.js#L9 ](https://github.com/Siilwyn/css-declaration-sorter-atom/blob/68825124d8c312376a4d809995935c1c1390aefb/spec/main-spec.js#L9) hasn't been updated, so the command "doesn't match".

Although `editor.GetGrammar()` is showing the expected CSS, the `data-grammar` property of the actual `workspaceElement` is still only `text plain null-grammar`. A workaround for now is [decreasing the editor specificity](https://github.com/Siilwyn/css-declaration-sorter-atom/pull/44/commits/95c1f2c47688d6629f0eed0b60e623472fa779f4).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Change editor grammar
2. See editor's `data-grammar` not being changed

**Expected behavior:** `data-grammar` to reflect the currently used grammar.

**Actual behavior:** `data-grammar` stays the same.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.19.3
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

data.title: Use fs-admin instead of runas
data.body: Now that we're [using](https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/247) `fs-admin` instead of `runas` in `text-buffer`, we can remove the few usages of `runas` in Atom itself and drop it as a dependency entirely, which will slightly reduce our bundle size and the amount of code we have to maintain.
